title: Was the human lifespan on average shorter in ancient times? - Quora

response.answer_text: Was the human lifespan on average shorter in ancient times? Dear Bryce What do you mean by ancient times? As medicine has improved infant mortality has decreased, the use of antibiotics such as penicillin in 1928 was a major advance. So in ‘ancient times’ if you survived childhood, were well feed, escaped any nasty bugs etc then people lived to the same ages as they do now. Just your chance was greatly reduced.

Of course, infant mortality, children working in dangerous work. Plagues like small pox, bubonic and flu wiping out families. Even the lucky ones that lived to be grandparents were aged badly much younger. A 65 year old farmer and wife were elderly. Now we live easy lives, vaccines have wiped out many childhood killers like small pox and polio. Even farm work has machines to do the hard labor. Now a 65 year old couple look like 45 did even 200 years ago. Medicine like heart bypass surgery extends lives and antibiotic and cancer treatment. Live was hard and dangerous thousands or millions of years ago with more starvation, and dying in childbirth.
